Cherry Springs State Park was one of several to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the Civilian Conservation Corps with a CCC reunion in the summer of 1983. On May 11, 1987, the Cherry Springs Picnic Pavilion was listed on the NRHP. None of the other remaining CCC structures in the park had retained its historic integrity sufficiently to be included on the NRHP. Cherry Springs began attracting stargazers in the early 1990s. In 1999 the "Dark Sky Fund" was established and continues "to enhance the stargazing and astronomy experience" by funding improvements at the park.{{cite web| title = The Dark Skies of Cherry Springs State Park| url = http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/stateparks/findapark/cherrysprings/cherrysprings-darkskies/index.htm| publisher = Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources| accessdate = March 11, 2009}} In 2000 Cherry Springs was officially named a "Dark Sky Park" by the DCNR, and that same year it became part of the [[Hills Creek State Park]] complex, an administrative grouping of eight state parks in Potter and [[Tioga County, Pennsylvania|Tioga]] counties. The headquarters for Cherry Springs are at nearby [[Lyman Run State Park]].{{cite news| url = http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12106011&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=4¤tPage=0| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714174750/http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12106011&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=4¤tPage=0| dead-url = yes| archive-date = July 14, 2011| title = Manager named at Hills Creek Lake| work = Wellsboro Gazette| date = February 2, 2000| page = 6| accessdate = April 9, 2009}} ''Note'': the eight parks in the Hills Creek State Park Complex are Cherry Springs, [[Colton Point State Park|Colton Point]], [[Denton Hill State Park|Denton Hill]], [[Hills Creek State Park|Hills Creek]], [[Leonard Harrison State Park|Leonard Harrison]], [[Lyman Run State Park|Lyman Run]], [[Patterson State Park|Patterson]], and [[Prouty Place State Park|Prouty Place]]. The National Public Observatory picked it "as the pilot for the Stars-n-Parks program" in April 2001. The DCNR acquired the Cherry Springs Airport in 2006 "to expand the overall Dark Sky observation area and allow for increased programming opportunities" at the park,{{cite web| title = Progress through Partnerships: A Three-Year Report on the Pennsylvania Wilds| url = http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/info/pawilds/progressthroughpartnerships.pdf| date = January 2007| publisher = Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources| accessdate = March 11, 2009}} and closed it in 2007.{{cite news| url = http://www.endeavornews.com/news/2008/0105/front_page/005.html| title = It was the news: stories of 2007| date = January 5, 2008| work = Endeavor News| accessdate = March 11, 2009}} On June 11, 2008, the International Dark-Sky Association named Cherry Springs State Park the second "International Dark Sky Park". (The first was [[Natural Bridges National Monument]] in [[Utah]].) In 2018, the section of [[Pennsylvania Route 44]] passing through the park was named Highway to the Stars, following an effort led by photographer Curt Weinhold, a Potter County resident, and legislation sponsored by State Representative [[Martin Causer]] and approved by Governor [[Tom Wolf]].{{cite news|last=Davis|first=Alex|title=Route 44, and Cherry Springs, designated as 'Highway to the Stars'|work=The Bradford Era|date=June 30, 2018|url=http://www.bradfordera.com/news/route-and-cherry-springs-designated-as-highway-to-the-stars/article_b7268660-7bf8-11e8-baca-27b9be778a4d.html|accessdate=October 20, 2018}} ==Geology and climate== [[File:Cherry Springs 1938 Aerial Photo Crop.jpg|thumb|right|1938 aerial view of the park, [[Cherry Springs Airport|airport]], PA 44, West Branch Pine Creek, and Hopper House Run]] Cherry Springs State Park is at an elevation of {{convert|2300|ft|0}} above sea level,{{cite web | url={{Gnis3|1171676}}| title=Cherry Springs State Park | date = August 30, 1990 | work=[[Geographic Names Information System]]| publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]]| accessdate=February 10, 2008}} atop the [[Allegheny Plateau]] and "near the glaciated boundary". The plateau and the [[Appalachian Mountains]] were all formed in the [[Alleghenian orogeny]] some 300 million years ago, when [[Gondwana]] (specifically what became Africa) and what became North America collided, forming [[Pangaea]]. Although the region appears mountainous, these are not true mountains: instead millions of years of [[erosion]] have made this a [[dissected plateau]], causing the "mountainous" terrain seen today. The hardest of the ancient rocks are on top of the ridges, while the softer rocks eroded away forming the valleys.{{cite book|title= The Geology of Pennsylvania|last= Shultz|first= Charles H. (Editor)|year= 1999|publisher= Pennsylvania Geological Society and Pittsburgh Geological Society|location= Harrisburg and Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|isbn= 0-8182-0227-0}} The park is in the [[West Branch Pine Creek]] drainage basin, where the underlying rocks are primarily [[conglomerate (geology)|conglomerate]], [[sandstone]], and [[shale]]. Two major rock formations are present in Cherry Springs State Park, both at least partly from the [[Carboniferous]] period. The youngest of these, which forms the highest points in the park, is the early [[Pennsylvanian (geology)|Pennsylvanian]] [[Pottsville Formation]], a gray conglomerate that may contain sandstone, [[siltstone]], and shale, as well as [[anthracite]] coal. The lower formation is the late [[Devonian]] and early [[Mississippian age|Mississippian]] [[Huntley Mountain Formation]], which is made of relatively soft grayish-red shale and olive-gray sandstone. Outside the park the creek has cut down into the Devonian [[Catskill Formation]], a reddish sandstone.{{cite book|title= Roadside Geology of Pennsylvania|last= Van Diver|first= Bradford B.|year= 1990|publisher= Mountain Press Publishing Company|location= Missoula, Montana|isbn= 0-87842-227-7|page= 115}}{{cite web| url = http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/topogeo/map61/conrad15ne.pdf| title = Atlas of Preliminary Geologic Quadrangle Maps of Pennsylvania: Cherry Springs| accessdate = March 8, 2009| author = Berg, T. M.|publisher = Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, Bureau of Topographic and Geologic Survey| year = 1981| format = PDF}}{{cite web| url = http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/topogeo/pub/map/pdfs/map067_tabloid_exp.pdf|title = Map 67: Tabloid Edition Explanation|publisher = Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, Bureau of Topographic and Geologic Survey|format = PDF|accessdate = June 3, 2008}} The Allegheny Plateau has a [[continental climate]], with occasional severe low temperatures in winter and average daily [[Diurnal temperature variation|temperature ranges]] of 20 °F (11 °C) in winter and 26 °F (14 °C) in summer.{{cite web|url=http://climate.met.psu.edu/data/ncdc_pa.pdf |format=PDF |title=Climate of Pennsylvania |publisher=Pennsylvania State University, Pennsylvania State Climatologist |accessdate=April 12, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090225124128/http://climate.met.psu.edu/data/ncdc_pa.pdf |archivedate=February 25, 2009 |df= }} The mean annual [[precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]] for the West Branch Pine Creek watershed is {{convert|40|to|42|in|mm|0}}.{{cite book| last = Shaw| first = Lewis C.| others = Prepared in Cooperation with the United States Department of the Interior Geological Survey| title = Pennsylvania Gazetteer of Streams Part II (Water Resources Bulletin No. 16)|date=June 1984| edition = 1st| publisher = Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, Department of Environmental Resources| location = Harrisburg, PA| page = 162 | oclc = 17150333}} January is the coldest month at Cherry Springs, July the warmest, and June the wettest. The highest recorded temperature at the park was {{convert|94|F}} in 1966, and the record low was {{convert|-28|F}} in 1963.{{cite web|title= Monthly Averages for Cherry Springs State Park|url= http://www.weather.com/outlook/recreation/outdoors/wxclimatology/monthly/PASPCS:13|accessdate= March 7, 2009|publisher= The Weather Channel Interactive, Inc|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090616151427/http://www.weather.com/outlook/recreation/outdoors/wxclimatology/monthly/PASPCS%3A13|archivedate= June 16, 2009|df= }} {{Weather box |location = Cherry Springs State Park |single line = Yes |Jan high F = 29 |Feb high F = 34 |Mar high F = 42 |Apr high F = 56 |May high F = 67 |Jun high F = 75 |Jul high F = 78 |Aug high F = 77 |Sep high F = 69 |Oct high F = 58 |Nov high F = 45 |Dec high F = 33 |Jan low F = 13 |Feb low F = 15 |Mar low F = 23 |Apr low F = 33 |May low F = 43 |Jun low F = 51 |Jul low F = 54 |Aug low F = 53 |Sep low F = 47 |Oct low F = 37 |Nov low F = 28 |Dec low F = 18 |Jan precipitation inch = 2.47 |Feb precipitation inch = 2.28 |Mar precipitation inch = 2.84 |Apr precipitation inch = 3.12 |May precipitation inch = 3.73 |Jun precipitation inch = 5.63 |Jul precipitation inch = 4.13 |Aug precipitation inch = 3.99 |Sep precipitation inch = 3.99 |Oct precipitation inch = 3.34 |Nov precipitation inch = 3.59 |Dec precipitation inch = 2.87 |source 1 = The Weather Channel |date=August 2010 }} ==Ecology== [[File:Northern Saw-whet Owl, Reifel BC 1.jpg|thumb|left|[[Northern saw-whet owl]]s have been studied in the park.]] Cherry Springs State Park and the surrounding Susquehannock State Forest have recovered from the clearcutting of the lumber era. However, the composition of the forests has changed, so that there are now more hardwoods, including [[Acer saccharum|sugar maple]] and black cherry, and fewer eastern white pine and eastern hemlock. The park also has apple trees from the CCC orchard. Over 400 species of birds have been found in Pennsylvania, including 186 that breed in the state.{{cite book|last= Audubon Pennsylvania|authorlink= National Audubon Society|author2= Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, Commonwealth of Pennsylvania|title= Susquehanna River Birding and Wildlife Trail|url= http://web1.audubon.org/trailMaps/|format= Searchable database|accessdate= March 8, 2009|location= Harrisburg, Pennsylvania|page= 2|year= 2004|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090131201609/http://web1.audubon.org/trailMaps/ |archivedate= January 31, 2009}} Birds such as [[osprey]]s, [[hawk]]s, [[owl]]s, [[nightjar]]s, and [[bald eagle]]s have returned to the park and state forest, and [[Northern saw-whet owl|saw-whet owls]] have been studied in the park.{{cite web| url = http://www.state.pa.us/papower/cwp/view.asp?A=11&Q=455724| title = Pennsylvania Wilds Discovery Weekend Offers Outdoor Adventure|publisher = Pennsylvania State Government|format = PDF|accessdate = June 3, 2008| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060923104813/http://www.state.pa.us/papower/cwp/view.asp?A=11&Q=455724| archivedate = September 23, 2006}} Some animals which had been locally extinct have also returned or been reintroduced to the area, including [[white-tailed deer]], [[elk]], [[Fisher (animal)|fishers]] (a type of weasel), and [[otter]]s. Although banned in the park, hunting is allowed in the surrounding state forest, which regained its title as a "sportsmen's paradise" in the 20th century. Game species include [[American black bear|black bears]], white-tailed deer, [[duck]]s, [[ruffed grouse]], [[Eastern cottontail|rabbits]], [[Eastern gray squirrel|gray]] and [[American red squirrel|red squirrels]], and [[wild turkey]]s. Other animals present in the park and forest include [[chipmunk]]s, [[American mink|minks]], [[raccoon]]s, [[porcupine]]s, [[groundhog]]s, and the occasional [[bobcat]], as well as [[frog]]s, [[beetle]]s, and [[moth]]s. A branch of Hopper House Run rises within the park, and flows east and then north into the West Branch Pine Creek. West Branch Road (or Branch Road) follows the valleys of the run and creek from Pennsylvania Route 44 east {{convert|10|mi}} to Galeton. PA 44 roughly follows the line dividing the Pine Creek watershed to the north and the [[Sinnemahoning Creek]] watershed to the south. East Fork Road leaves PA 44 in the park and follows the East Fork Sinnemahoning Creek valley southwest {{convert|12|mi}} to the village of Conrad.{{cite map| title = Cherry Springs State Park| url = http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/stateparks/parks/cherrysprings/cherrysprings_mini.pdf| date = January 2008| publisher = Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources| accessdate = March 10, 2009}} ''Note'': One spring feeding Hopper House Run is between the Cherry Springs Tavern and the parking lot ([[:File:Cherry Springs State Park Spring1.jpg|photo]]), while another is between PA Route 44 and West Branch Road, just east of their junction ([[:File:Cherry Springs State Park Spring 2.jpg|photo]]). Both creeks are approved [[trout]] streams for fishing, which means they are [[fish stocking|stocked]] with trout in season.{{cite web| url = http://pfbc.state.pa.us/CountyGuide/countyguide.htm| title = PFBC County Guide| publisher = [[Pennsylvania Fish and Boat Commission]]| work = Searchable interactive map| accessdate = March 10, 2009| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100322235030/http://pfbc.state.pa.us/CountyGuide/countyguide.htm| archivedate = March 22, 2010| df = }} ==Recreation== ===Dark skies=== [[File:M20-Combine1B.jpg|thumb|upright|right|The [[Trifid Nebula]] (M20) in Sagittarius, as seen from the park ]]Astronomers and stargazers appreciate Cherry Springs State Park for the darkness and clarity of its skies, which make it "perhaps the last best refuge of the natural night sky" in the eastern half of the United States. The sky at Cherry Springs has been classified as a 2 on the [[Bortle Dark-Sky Scale]], meaning it has almost no [[light pollution]].{{cite web| url = http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/info/wind/documents/cherry-springs-state-park-light-pollution-analysis-05-29-08.pdf| title = Cherry Springs State Park: Light Pollution Analysis and Recommendations| publisher = Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources| date = May 27, 2008| author = Clanton & Associates| accessdate = March 21, 2009}} Such "truly dark, starry skies are unavailable to two-thirds of the world's population, including 99 percent of people in the continental U.S. and Western Europe". With optimum conditions, 10,000 stars are visible with the [[naked eye]] at the park, clouds appear only as black holes in the starry sky, and the [[Milky Way]] is so bright that it casts a discernible shadow. In contrast, big city residents can see a few dozen stars at best, and even those in rural areas can typically only see 2,000–3,000 stars. The Milky Way cannot be seen by most in the eastern US, even when there is no moonlight to obscure it. The quality of the night skies at the park and its growing popularity for stargazing are the result of several factors. Cherry Springs is in the midst of the largely undeveloped {{convert|262000|acre|adj=on}} Susquehannock State Forest, and is on a summit {{convert|2300|ft|0}} above sea level. Because it is on the Allegheny Plateau, there are no mountain peaks to block the sky, and the Astronomy Field offers a 360 degree unobstructed view. The closest city is Williamsport, {{convert|60|mi}} to the southeast. Surrounding communities sit in deep valleys, so the intervening terrain screens much of the light they produce; the park has no artificial [[skyglow]] in any direction. Cherry Springs is generally fog-free and its latitude puts it in excellent position to observe the [[Galactic Center]] of the Milky Way. The remote location also means there is little commercial air traffic to interfere with [[astrophotography]], while PA Route 44 still offers relatively easy access to the park from [[Interstate 80 in Pennsylvania|Interstate 80]]. In addition to these natural factors, much has been done intentionally to make the skies at the park clear and dark and help keep them that way. Within the park, former overhead electrical lines have been buried so they do not obstruct views, all lighting is shielded, and all white lights have been converted to red, which has the least effect on [[night vision]] and astrophotography. Light from passing vehicles is blocked by earthen [[berm]]s covered with grass, or shrubbery and spruce trees; the Astronomy Field gate has a special light-blocking tarp. The park's Dark Sky Fund has paid for many of these improvements since 1999.{{cite news| title = 'Awesome': Stargazers revel in Cherry Springs’ dark skies| last = Lamey| first = Jessica| date = June 29, 2008| pages = E1, E3| work = [[Williamsport Sun-Gazette]]| url = http://www.sungazette.com/page/content.detail/id/512360.html?nav=5013| accessdate = March 23, 2009}} [[File:Snowy Domes - Cherry Springs SP.jpg|thumb|left|Two of the park's three astronomy domes; the walls prevent the wind from moving telescopes during observation]] Since the 2006 acquisition of the Cherry Springs airport, a new Public Programming field has been established on the former airstrip. This field is northeast of PA Route 44 and is intended for educational programs or stargazing, but not for those who spend the night. Overnight observers and those with large telescopes use the Astronomy Field southwest of the highway. Nighttime visitors may only use flashlights with red filters, and may only point them at the ground. The Astronomy Field has further restrictions on lights, and parts of the park are light-free zones. To help preserve the dark skies at Cherry Springs State Park, Tri-County Rural Electric company installs light-shielding caps on outdoor lights at local homes for free. In 2001 the Pennsylvania General Assembly passed the "Outdoor Lighting Control Act", which both established the park as a "Dark Sky Preserve" and required minimal and shielded lighting at all new state facilities to reduce light pollution.{{cite web| url = http://www.legis.state.pa.us/CFDOCS/Legis/PN/Public/btCheck.cfm?txtType=PDF&sessYr=2001&sessInd=0&billBody=H&billTyp=B&billNbr=0300&pn=2860| title = An Act Providing for management of outdoor night lighting (House Bill No. 300, Session of 2001)| publisher = The General Assembly of Pennsylvania| date = November 13, 2001| accessdate = March 23, 2009}} A design guide for the Pennsylvania Wilds region, which includes the park, emphasizes the importance of maintaining dark skies.{{cite web| url = http://www.clintoncountypa.com/PA%20Wilds/PA%20Wilds%20Guide/PA%20Wilds%20Design%20Guide2.pdf| title = Pennsylvania Wilds Design Guide" A Design Guide for Community Character Stewardship| author = The Pennsylvania Wilds Planning Team| publisher = [[Clinton County, Pennsylvania]]| date = February 13, 2009| accessdate = March 29, 2009}} The DCNR spent $396,000 in June 2007 to buy [[mineral rights]] under {{convert|1980|acre}} of the park and state forest to prevent [[natural gas]] drilling and associated development there.{{cite news| url = http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/09123/967360-113.stm| title = Goddard State Park's gas wells may be first of hundreds: Where mineral rights are privately owned, Pennsylvania officials can't prevent drilling| date = May 3, 2009| first = Don| last = Hopey| work = [[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]| accessdate = May 6, 2009}} A [[wind farm]] has been proposed on a site {{convert|13.7|mi}} from the park. In 2008 Potter County passed an ordinance that [[wind turbine]] lights shall not "interfere with the state-designated Dark Skies Preserve at Cherry Springs State Park".{{cite web| url = http://www.pottercountypa.net/planning/saldo/Article12.doc| title = Potter County Wind Energy Ordinance| date = 2008| publisher = [[Potter County, Pennsylvania]]| accessdate = March 29, 2009}} That same year the DCNR commissioned a study on the wind farm's impact, which concluded the red warning lights on the wind turbines would not impact the darkness of the sky and would only be directly visible from the Astronomy Field under rare conditions. Others in the astronomy community challenged these conclusions and feared that new lights on "several dozen wind turbines near the park" will degrade observations and astrophotography.{{cite web| url = http://www.skyandtelescope.com/news/21914474.html| title = Cherry Springs Earns Dark-Sky Status| author = Beatty, Kelly| work = [[Sky and Telescope]]| date = June 27, 2008| accessdate = March 27, 2009| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130202185608/http://www.skyandtelescope.com/news/21914474.html| archivedate = February 2, 2013| df = }} The study also recommended that the DCNR shield and redirect lights at the nearby [[Denton Hill State Park]] downhill ski area to make the sky even darker at Cherry Springs.{{cite news| title = State: Proposed wind farm would not affect dark skies at Cherry Springs State Park| date = June 29, 2008| page = E3| work = [[Williamsport Sun-Gazette]]| url =http://www.sungazette.com/page/content.detail/id/512363.html| accessdate = March 23, 2009}} ===Astronomical observing=== [[File:Cherry Springs telescopes.jpg|thumb|Telescopes belonging to amateur astronomers await nightfall.]] The staff at Cherry Springs State Park did not intend for it to become an attraction for amateur astronomers; the astronomers came to them instead. In 1997 or 1998 Chip Harrison, the park supervisor, noticed a man looking through a telescope at the park at about 1 AM.{{cite web| url = http://travel.nytimes.com/2007/09/14/travel/escapes/14dark.html| title = Dark Sky, Bright Lights Over Pennsylvania| first = Dave| last = Caldwell| date = September 14, 2007| accessdate = February 1, 2009| work = [[The New York Times]]}}{{cite news| title = Pennsylvania peak is heaven for stargazers| last = Nephin| first = Dan| date = September 15, 2006| url = http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/06258/721452-37.stm| agency= [[Associated Press]] |work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|accessdate = March 23, 2009}} When Harrison asked why the man had come there, the astronomer said he had noticed an isolated black patch over north central Pennsylvania on nighttime satellite photos. Cherry Springs State Park is in that patch, one of the best locations east of the [[Mississippi River]] for [[Amateur astronomy|stargazing]]. An increasing number of astronomers began to come to Cherry Springs, most in the 14-day dark sky period around the [[new moon]], between the last quarter and first quarter phases. The park is open year-round and between 60 and 85 nights each year have ideal conditions, when the [[apparent magnitude]]s of the faintest stars visible can range from 7.1 to 7.5. The park's Astronomy Field has been upgraded to accommodate these astronomers. In 2005 a rotating {{convert|15|ft|adj=on}} slotted observatory dome, two {{convert|12|ft|adj=on}} clamshell domes, and a {{convert|10|by|12|ft|adj=on}} sky shed were added, as well as a small amphitheater for programs. The four structures protect telescopes from the wind and thermal currents. The next year concrete pads {{convert|4|and|6|ft|}} in diameter were placed at random in the field, and electrical pedestals, each with six outlets, were added to power telescopes and computers. In 2009, [[Wi-Fi]] internet access was added to the Astronomy Field.{{cite web| url = http://www.astrohbg.org/CSSP/Information.html| title = 2009 Cherry Springs Star Party| publisher = The Astronomical Society of Harrisburg, Pennsylvania| accessdate = May 6, 2009| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090318095738/http://astrohbg.org/CSSP/Information.html| archivedate = March 18, 2009| df = }} [[File:M51a.jpg|thumb|left|The [[Whirlpool Galaxy]] (M51) in the constellation [[Canes Venatici]], as seen from the Astronomy Field]] While a typical clear night might have 50 to 100 observers, each year the park hosts two major [[star party|star parties]] which both attract several hundred astronomers for several nights. The Black Forest Star Party, sponsored by the Central Pennsylvania Observers of [[State College, Pennsylvania|State College]], has been held each fall since 1999.{{cite web|url=http://www.bfsp.org/starparty/about.cfm |title=About the Black Forest Star Party |publisher=Central Pennsylvania Observers, Inc. |accessdate=March 29, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090616124513/http://www.bfsp.org/starparty/about.cfm |archivedate=June 16, 2009 |df= }} The Cherry Springs Star Party, sponsored by the Astronomical Society of [[Harrisburg, Pennsylvania|Harrisburg]], has been held each June since 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.astrohbg.org/CSSP/Schedule.html |title=Cherry Springs Star Party 2009 Schedule |publisher=The Astronomical Society of Harrisburg, Pennsylvania |accessdate=March 29, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090330081514/http://www.astrohbg.org/CSSP/Schedule.html |archivedate=March 30, 2009 |df= }} There are also free public programs at the amphitheater on the former airport site, some of which are part of the National Public Observatory's Stars-n-Parks program. [[Meteor shower]]s will also attract a crowd and the [[Aurora (astronomy)|Aurora Borealis]] can be seen from the park. A stargazing business, "Crystal Spheres", has been established and presents Music and Stars programs, with an hour-long concert followed by an hour of stargazing.{{cite web| url = http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/info/pawilds/0706-twotw.aspx| title = A PA Wilds Business Success Story: The Sky’s the Limit for Astronomy in Potter County| author = Morey, Tim| publisher = Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources| date = June 2007| accessdate = March 29, 2009}} Such "nature tourism" has a positive economic impact for the area.{{cite news| url = http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=29872600&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=0¤tPage=0| title = Volunteer receives DCNR award| last = August| first = Henry| date = April 9, 2003| work = Wellsboro Gazette (The Marketplace)| accessdate = March 29, 2009| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714174719/http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=29872600&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=0¤tPage=0| archive-date = 2011-07-14| dead-url = yes| df = }} Awards and press recognition have come to Cherry Springs and its staff. Thom Bemus, who initiated and coordinates the Stars-n-Parks program, was named DCNR's 2002 Volunteer of the Year. In 2007 the park's Dark Sky Programming and staff received the Environmental Education Excellence in Programming award from the Pennsylvania Recreation and Parks Society.{{cite news| url = http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=131773422&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=1¤tPage=0| title = Cherry Springs wins environmental award| date = 2007-05-30| work = Wellsboro Gazette (The Marketplace)| accessdate = March 29, 2009| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714174857/http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=131773422&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=1¤tPage=0| archive-date = 2011-07-14| dead-url = yes| df = }} Operations manager Chip Harrison and his wife Maxine, who directs the Dark Sky Fund, received a 2008 award from the Pennsylvania Outdoor Lighting Council for "steadfast adherence and active promotion of the principles of responsible outdoor lighting at Cherry Springs State Park".{{cite news| url = http://www.sungazette.com/page/content.detail/id/515859.html| title = Cherry Springs State Park team of husband-wife receives award| date = September 21, 2008|work = [[Williamsport Sun-Gazette]] | accessdate = March 29, 2009}} The DCNR has named Cherry Springs one of "25 Must-See Pennsylvania State Parks", specifically for having the "darkest night skies on the east coast".{{cite web| url = http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/stateparks/findapark/index.htm | title = Find a Park: Twenty Must-see Parks | accessdate = November 26, 2011 | publisher = Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources}} ''Note: Despite the title, there are twenty-one parks in the list, with [[Colton Point State Park|Colton Point]] and [[Leonard Harrison State Park]]s treated as one.'' Cherry Springs State Park was featured in the national press in 2003 when ''[[USA Today]]'' named it one of "10 Great Places to get some stars in your eyes",{{cite news| url = https://www.usatoday.com/travel/destinations/10great/2003-09-29-star-gazing_x.htm| title = 10 Great Places to get some stars in your eyes| date = July 31, 2003| work = [[USA Today]]| accessdate = March 29, 2009}} in 2006 when ''[[National Geographic Adventure Magazine|National Geographic Adventure]]'' featured it in "Pennsylvania: The Wild, Wild East",{{cite journal|last= Minarcek|first= Andrea|date= May 2006|title= Pennsylvania: The Wild, Wild East|journal= [[National Geographic Adventure Magazine|National Geographic Adventure]]|accessdate= March 30, 2009|url= http://www.nationalgeographic.com/adventure/travel/pennsylvania.html|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060524133907/http://www.nationalgeographic.com/adventure/travel/pennsylvania.html|archivedate= May 24, 2006|df= }} and in ''[[The New York Times]]'' in 2007. All these were before it was named an International Dark Sky Park by the [[International Dark-Sky Association]] in 2008.{{cite web| url = http://weblogs.marylandweather.com/2008/06/pa_park_wins_dark_sky_designat.html| title = Pa. park wins "dark sky" designation| accessdate = June 21, 2008| author = Frank Roylance| publisher = [[The Baltimore Sun]] / MarylandWeather.com}} ===Woodsmen's Show=== [[File:Phot cherryshow2.jpg|thumb|A chainsaw event at the Woodsmen's Show]] The Woodsmen's Show attracts thousands of visitors to Cherry Springs State Park on the first weekend in August. It has been held every year since 1952, and has been sponsored by the [[Galeton, Pennsylvania|Galeton]] Rotary Club since 1987. In 2008 events at the three-day show included tree-felling, cross-cutting, [[logrolling (sport)|log rolling]], axe-throwing, [[horse pulling]], spring board chopping, the standing block chop, and [[chainsaw]] competitions and demonstrations. The 2008 show also featured historic recreations of life in a logging camp, musical performances, and vendors selling food, crafts, and equipment related to the lumber industry.{{cite web| url = http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/stateparks/findapark/cherrysprings/index.htm| title = Cherry Springs State Park| accessdate = November 4, 2008| publisher = Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources}}{{cite web| url = http://www.woodsmenshow.com/MAJOR%20EVENTS.htm| title = 57th Annual Woodsmen's Show| accessdate = February 11, 2009| publisher = T. Dennison Promotions| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090616112251/http://www.woodsmenshow.com/MAJOR%20EVENTS.htm| archivedate = June 16, 2009| df = }}{{cite news| url = http://www.sungazette.com/page/content.detail/id/513424.html| title = Cherry Springs State Park hosts 57th edition of Woodsmen’s Show| last = Lamey| first = Jessica| date = July 27, 2008| work = [[Williamsport Sun-Gazette]]| accessdate = April 6, 2009}} The show and its events, which celebrate Potter County's lumbering history, have changed with time. In the early years, up to three working sawmills were set up just for the carnival,{{cite news| url = http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12215681&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=3¤tPage=0| title = Ann'l Woodsmen's Carnival Aug. 5–6, Cherry Springs Park| date = August 4, 1956| page = 7| work = Wellsboro Agitator| accessdate = April 6, 2009| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714175054/http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12215681&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=3¤tPage=0| archive-date = 2011-07-14| dead-url = yes| df = }} and there was an associated Woodsmen's Ball on Saturday evening, after the carnival ended. The Woodsmen's Show had its first female competitor in 1979.{{cite news| url = http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=14477673&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=4¤tPage=0| title = Woodsmen's Show – Largest Yet| date = August 8, 1979| page = 4| work = Wellsboro Gazette| accessdate = April 6, 2009| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714174737/http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=14477673&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=4¤tPage=0| archive-date = 2011-07-14| dead-url = yes| df = }} Some events have been tried and discontinued; in 1987 one-hour seminars on topics such as "Outdoor Adventures on Mules" and the first "Woodsmen's Carnival Queen" were introduced,{{cite news| url = http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=14511071&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=5¤tPage=0| title = Lots going on at woodsmen's carnival| date = July 8, 1987| page = 7| work = Wellsboro Gazette| accessdate = April 6, 2009| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714175505/http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=14511071&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=5¤tPage=0| archive-date = 2011-07-14| dead-url = yes| df = }} and in 1993 there was [[tractor pulling]] with [[lawn mower|lawn tractors]].{{cite news| url = http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12385470&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=0¤tPage=0| title = Potter County's annual Woodsmen's Show buzzes into Cherry Springs State Park| date = July 28, 1993| page = 15| work = Wellsboro Gazette| accessdate = April 6, 2009| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714175348/http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12385470&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=0¤tPage=0| archive-date = 2011-07-14| dead-url = yes| df = }} In 1990 the name was changed from the "Woodsmen's Carnival" to the "Woodsmen's Show", a third day was added, and an ecumenical church service was held Sunday morning in the large picnic pavilion. The next year the show was part of the [[STIHL Timbersports Series]] and some of the competition was televised on [[ESPN]].{{cite news| url = http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12327062&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=3¤tPage=0| title = Annual Woodsmen's show to open at Cherry Springs| date = July 24, 1991| page = 19| work = Wellsboro Gazette| accessdate = April 6, 2009| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714175752/http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12327062&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=3¤tPage=0| archive-date = 2011-07-14| dead-url = yes| df = }} Although it is no longer part of the STIHL series, as of 2008 many of the same athletes competed at the show. Attendance was 4,000 the first year and grew to 12,000 three years later in 1955,{{cite news| url = http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12219153&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=0¤tPage=0| title = Woodsmen Hold Carnival August 3, Cherry Springs Park| date = July 26, 1956| page = 1| work = Wellsboro Agitator| accessdate = April 6, 2009| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714175048/http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12219153&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=0¤tPage=0| archive-date = 2011-07-14| dead-url = yes| df = }} then peaked at 33,000 in 1962, with nearly as many in 1965 (32,000) and 1981 (30,000).{{cite news| url = http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12109868&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=7¤tPage=10| title = Woodsmen's Carnival Attracts 33,000 Persons Winners Announced| date = August 9, 1962| page = 8| work = Wellsboro Agitator| accessdate = April 6, 2009| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714175206/http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12109868&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=7¤tPage=10| archive-date = 2011-07-14| dead-url = yes| df = }}{{cite news| url = http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12124813&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=8¤tPage=10| title = Annual Woodsmen's Carnival Aug. 5–6 Arena Enlarged| date = July 7, 1966| page = 12| work = Wellsboro Agitator| accessdate = April 6, 2009| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714175220/http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12124813&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=8¤tPage=10| archive-date = 2011-07-14| dead-url = yes| df = }}{{cite news| url = http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12209540&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=7¤tPage=0| title = Woodsmen's Carnival is Success| date = August 5, 1981| page = 17| work = Wellsboro Gazette| accessdate = April 7, 2009| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714180127/http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12209540&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=7¤tPage=0| archive-date = 2011-07-14| dead-url = yes| df = }} In 1983, 20,000 visitors came to the show,{{cite news| url = http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12222660&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=3¤tPage=0| title = Woodsmen's Carnival A Success? ... You Bet!| date = August 10, 1983| page = 19| work = Wellsboro Gazette| accessdate = April 6, 2009| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714174726/http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=12222660&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=3¤tPage=0| archive-date = 2011-07-14| dead-url = yes| df = }} 15,000 came in 1985,{{cite news| url = http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=14493088&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=0¤tPage=0| title = 15,000 Attend Woodsmen's Show| date = August 7, 1985| page = 25| work = Wellsboro Gazette| accessdate = April 6, 2009| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714175321/http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=14493088&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=0¤tPage=0| archive-date = 2011-07-14| dead-url = yes| df = }} and by the early 21st century attendance was about 14,000. Admission is charged and cash prizes are awarded in the competitions. Proceeds from the show under the Penn-York Lumbermen's Club went to promote the lumber industry and support the [[Pennsylvania Lumber Museum]]. The Galeton Rotary Club has used the funds to improve the [[standard of living]] in and around Galeton, including [[scholarship|college scholarships]], a new roof for the community building, support for the local [[public library]], and clean-up and maintenance of the downtown area.{{cite web| url = http://www.woodsmenshow.com/galeton_rotary_club.htm| title = Galeton Rotary Club| accessdate = February 10, 2009| publisher = T. Dennison Promotions| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20040402101121/http://www.woodsmenshow.com/galeton_rotary_club.htm| archivedate = April 2, 2004| df = }} ===Camping, picnicking, and trails=== [[File:Cherry Springs State Park Camping Area 2.jpg|thumb|left|The camping area at the park, with picnic tables]] {{Mapbox|type=shape|text=Map Highlighting the Park's Boundaries|stroke-color=#00ff00}} The park has 30 camping sites which can each accommodate a tent, or a [[recreational vehicle]] (RV) up to {{convert|30|ft}} long. The sites all have a fire ring, lantern hanger, and picnic table, and are classified as rustic because they have no running water. The camping area, which is southeast of Pennsylvania Route 44, is open from April to December and does accept reservations. The park has two modern latrines, one in the camping area and the other at the Astronomy Field. There is also a [[holding tank dump station]] for RVs.{{cite book| url = https://books.google.com/?id=-5EWcHhCUSwC&pg=PA89&dq=cherry+Springs+Camping+moon| title = Pennsylvania Camping: The Complete Guide to Tent and RV Camping| series = Moon Outdoors| last = Miller| first = Jason| first2 = Heidi Ruby| last2 = Miller| others = Miller, Jason Jack (photographer)| publisher = Avalon Travel Publishing| date = 2006| isbn = 978-1-56691-986-9}}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web| url = http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/stateparks/findapark/cherrysprings/index.htm | title = Cherry Springs State Park | accessdate = November 12, 2014| publisher = Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources}} Although the Astronomy Field is not an official camping area, overnight observers may set up tents and vehicles there in which to camp. In addition to the picnic tables and small pavilion in the camping area, the main picnic area at Cherry Springs is on the southwest side of Route 44, in and around the large historic, CCC-built pavilion. The area surrounding the pavilion has many picnic tables situated in an old [[apple]] [[orchard]] and a stand of huge [[Eastern white pine|white pine]] and [[Norway spruce]] trees. Cherry Springs State Park is at the southern end of a {{convert|15|mi|adj=on}} long, single-track [[mountain bike]] trail, which begins at [[Denton Hill State Park]] and passes through [[Patterson State Park]].{{cite web | url = http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/stateparks/findapark/patterson/index.htm| title = Patterson State Park | accessdate = November 4, 2006 | publisher = Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources}} In 2005 the [[snowmobile]] [[trailhead]] at Cherry Springs was moved to the southern end of the park to avoid the Astronomy Field.{{cite news| url = http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=74402018&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=0¤tPage=0| title = Cherry Springs State Park snowmobile trailhead relocated| work = Wellsboro Gazette| date = November 30, 2005| page = 14| accessdate = April 6, 2009| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714180134/http://greenfreelibrary.newspaperarchive.com/PdfViewer.aspx?img=74402018&firstvisit=true&src=search¤tResult=0¤tPage=0| archive-date = 2011-07-14| dead-url = yes| df = }} The snowmobile trail is one of many trails available for [[cross-country skiing]], backpacking, hiking, and [[all-terrain vehicle]] and horseback riding in the surrounding Susquehannock State Forest. The {{convert|85|mi|adj=on}} long [[Susquehannock Trail System]] passes close to the park and loops around it. South of the park the trail passes through the [[Hammersley Wild Area]], which at {{convert|30253|acre}} without roads is the second largest wild area in Pennsylvania.{{cite web| url = http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/news/resource/res2004/01-hammersley.aspx| title = Hammersley Wild Area becomes official| date = January 2004| accessdate = April 6, 2009| publisher = Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources| work = The Resource}} ==Nearby state parks== Cherry Springs State Park is on Pennsylvania Route 44 in West Branch Township, {{convert|10|mi}} southwest of Galeton.{{cite web | url = http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/stateparks/findapark/where/index.htm | title = Find a Park by Region (interactive map) | accessdate = November 18, 2011 | publisher = [[Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources]] }} The following state parks are within {{convert|30|mi}} of Cherry Springs State Park:{{cite map| scale= 1:65,000| publisher= Pennsylvania Department of Transportation, Bureau of Planning and Research, Geographic Information Division| url= http://www.dot7.state.pa.us/BPR_pdf_files/Maps/GHS/Roadnames/potter_GHSN.PDF| title= 2007 General Highway Map Potter County Pennsylvania| accessdate= July 27, 2007}} ''Note: shows Cherry Springs State Park'' {{colbegin}} * [[Bucktail State Park Natural Area]] ([[Cameron County, Pennsylvania|Cameron]] and [[Clinton County, Pennsylvania|Clinton Counties]]) * [[Colton Point State Park]] ([[Tioga County, Pennsylvania|Tioga County]]) * [[Denton Hill State Park]] (Potter County) * [[Hyner Run State Park]] (Clinton County) * [[Hyner View State Park]] (Clinton County) * [[Kettle Creek State Park]] (Clinton Counties) * [[Leonard Harrison State Park]] (Tioga County) * [[Lyman Run State Park]] (Potter County) * [[Ole Bull State Park]] (Potter County) * [[Patterson State Park]] (Potter County) * [[Prouty Place State Park]] (Potter County) * [[Sinnemahoning State Park]] (Cameron and Potter Counties) * [[Sizerville State Park]] (Cameron and Potter Counties) {{colend}} {{Panorama |image = File:Cherry Springs State Park panorama.jpg |caption = Panoramic view of the park, left to right: astronomy bulletin board, CCC-built picnic pavilion, pumphouse, Astronomy Field, sky shed and three astronomy observation domes, information display, modern latrines, amphitheater, and CCC-built replica of the Cherry Springs Tavern (log cabin across [[Pennsylvania Route 44]]) |height = 300 }} ==Notes== {{refbegin}} :'''a.''' {{Note label|A|a|none}}As of April 2009, the official website for Cherry Springs State Park still lists the area as {{convert|48|acre}}, as does Forrey's 1984 ''History of Pennsylvania's State Parks''. This was the size of the park before the [[Cherry Springs Airport]] was closed and much of its land was transferred to the park. When built the airport was {{convert|40|acre}}, and it had expanded in size to {{convert|59|acre}} by 1981.{{cite web| work = [[Geographic Names Information System]]| publisher = [[United States Geological Survey]]| date = August 30, 1990| url ={{Gnis3|1194270}}| title = Cherry Springs Airport| accessdate =2009-03-30}} The airport land was owned by the Bureau of Forestry, which is part of the DCNR along with the Bureau of State Parks.{{cite web|url=http://www.gcr1.com/5010web/main.cfm?Site=5G6 |title=Cherry Springs Airport |author=[[Federal Aviation Administration]] |publisher=Public 5010 Web |accessdate=2009-03-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090616112351/http://www.gcr1.com/5010web/main.cfm?Site=5G6 |archivedate=2009-06-16 |df= }} As of January 30, 2015, the official website for Cherry Springs State Park states that it covers 82 acres. {{cite web| url = http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/stateparks/findapark/cherrysprings/index.htm|title = Cherry Springs State Park}} :'''b.''' {{Note label|B|b|none}}Although the park was along the {{convert|6.5|mi|adj=on}} Cherry Springs Drive, the exact endpoints of the drive are not clear. Two vistas are southeast of the park on Pennsylvania Route 44: it is {{convert|3.1|mi}} from the park to Water Tank Hollow Vista (which looks north), and {{convert|1.8|mi}} from the park to Cherry Springs Vista (which looks south). The Cherry Springs [[fire lookout tower|fire tower]] is {{convert|1.9|mi}} south of the park, just south of Cherry Springs vista.{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.com/outlook/driving/scenicdrives/?sd=paalleghenyplateau.jsp¶m1=USPA1799¶m2=USPA0930¶m3=USPA0339 |title=Pennsylvania: Allegheny Plateau Scenic Drive |publisher=The Weather Channel |accessdate=2009-04-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090329182155/http://www.weather.com/outlook/driving/scenicdrives/?sd=paalleghenyplateau.jsp¶m1=USPA1799¶m2=USPA0930¶m3=USPA0339 |archivedate=2009-03-29 |df= }} This cites {{cite book| title = Scenic Driving Pennsylvania| last = Ostertag| first = George| last2= Ostertag| first2 = Rhonda| publisher = Falcon Press Publishing Co| location = Helena, Montana| year = 1999| isbn = 1-56044-732-X}} [[Coudersport, Pennsylvania|Coudersport]] is {{convert|15|mi}} northwest of the park along Route 44, and the Cherry Springs "Class B" public campground was about {{convert|11|mi}} from Coudersport, or about {{convert|4|mi}} from the current park.{{cite book| title = Bulletin: In Penn's woods. A handy and helpful pocket manual of the natural wonders and recreational facilities of the state forests of Pennsylvania| last = Illick| first = Joseph S.| first2 = Henry W.| last2 = Shoemaker| publisher = Pennsylvania Dept. of Forests and Waters| url = https://books.google.com/?id=bO5DAAAAIAAJ&dq=%22cherry+springs+drive%22&q=%22cherry+springs%22| year = 1925| pages = 39–41}} As of 2009 this area is part of the state forest, but does not have any park facilities. The [[United States Geological Survey]] topographic map (Ayers Hill quadrant) does show a "Little Cherry Springs Park" in this area.{{cite web| url={{Gnis3|1179501}}| title= Little Cherry Springs Park| date = August 2, 1979| work=[[Geographic Names Information System]]| publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]]| accessdate=2009-04-07}} Patterson State Park is a short distance northwest of the site of Little Cherry Springs Park, and it is {{convert|6.5|mi}} along PA 44 from Patterson to the Cherry Springs vista. {{refend}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons {{Refimprove|date=December 2012}} {{Inappropriate tone|date=April 2016}} [[File:Model "S" Convection Heater - 1924.png|thumb|Illustration of the Model "S" Convection Heater by Sala Heater & Mantel, 1924]]
A '''convection heater''' is a [[heater]] which operates by air [[convection]] currents circulating through the body of the appliance, and across its [[heating element]]. This heats up the air, causing it to increase in volume and so become buoyant and rise. [[Oil heater]]s are an example of this kind of heating appliance. A convection heater may have an electrical heater element, a hot water coil, or a steam coil. Because of the natural ventilation, they are quieter in operation than [[fan heater]]s.
The Model “S”, here as illustrated in 1924, is an example of an early model convection space heater, by the Sala Heater & Mantel Co. in Dallas, Texas. The Model "S" was considered to be highly efficient radiant type of gas heater at the time. The heater utilizes radiant heat, and, by virtue of draft construction, supplements its power by drawing cold air through the facing, heating it and forcing it into the room through the register. This not only forces the circulation that provides an even warmth in every section of the room, but enables the heater to operate at all times with a perfectly cool exterior. Positive circulation provides an even warmth throughout the room, and guarantees a clean, humid, healthful{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} air to occupants.
The mixing chamber, due to its exclusive construction, utilizes centrifugal force to insure a perfect mixture between the gas and air, which in turn provides complete combustion, thus preventing dangerous fumes. After the gas leaves the mixing chamber it passes into a distribution chamber whose shape is such that an equal amount of gas passes into each jet, giving uniform flame height and also intensity.<ref name='Model "S" Convection Heater'>{{cite web|last=Sala|first=Theodore|title=The Sala Model S|url=http://www.salaair.com/salahistory.htm|work=Sala Heater Catalog 1924|publisher=Sala Heater and Mantel Co.|accessdate=1 September 2012}}</ref>
Due to the rising warm air from convector heaters, warm air may accumulate at the ceiling of the room. Therefore, convector heaters are often paired with ceiling fans, especially in rooms with tall ceilings. In the winter, setting a fan to turn clockwise will allow for more air circulation and will keep heat from rising completely, making the room feel warmer and allowing one to turn down the thermostat.
==See also== {{Portal|Energy}} * [[Radiator (heating)|Radiator]] * [[Electric heating]] * [[Radiator|Radiators and convectors]] * [[Radiator Heater Price|[https://buyerflow.com/best-room-heater-in-india/ Radiators and convectors]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}2. blog.fanimation.com - "5 Myths About Ceiling Fans: Busted"{{HVAC |state=collapsed}}
[[Category:Heaters]] [[Category:Convection]]
{{energy-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Czech [[Hydrometeorological]] Institute''' ('''CHMI''') ({{lang-cs|Český hydrometeorologický ústav (ČHMÚ)}}) is within the [[Ministry of the Environment (Czech Republic)|Environmental Ministry]] of the [[Czech Republic]]. The head office and centralized workplaces of the CHMI, including the data processing, telecommunication and technical services, are located at the Institute's own campus in [[Prague]]. The CHMI has five major divisions:<ref>[http://www.chmi.cz/portal/dt?portal_lang=en&menu=JSPTabContainer/P5_0_O_nas/P5_3_Organizacni_struktura&last=false] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150922043341/http://www.chmi.cz/portal/dt?portal_lang=en&menu=JSPTabContainer%2FP5_0_O_nas%2FP5_3_Organizacni_struktura&last=false |date=2015-09-22 }}</ref>
*[[Air quality|Air Quality]] Protection *[[Meteorology]] and Climatology *[[Hydrology]] *Finance and Administration *Information Technology
==History==
The National Meteorological Institute was established in 1919 shortly after the [[Czechoslovakia|Czechoslovak Republic]] was established at the end of [[World War I]]. On January 1, 1954, the National Meteorological Institute was united with the hydrology service and the Czech Hydrometeorological Institute was established. Its charter was amended in 1994 and in 1995 by the Ministry of the Environment of the Czech Republic.
==Air pollution dispersion modelling activities==
The Air Quality Protection division has seven departments:<ref>[http://www.chmi.cz/uoco/struct/structe.html Structure of CHMI's Air Quality Control Division] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061002204554/http://www.chmi.cz/uoco/struct/structe.html |date=2006-10-02 }}</ref>
*Air Quality Information System *[[Air pollution|Emission]] and Sources *[[Atmospheric dispersion modeling|Modelling]] and Expertise Pool *National Inventorization System *Air Quality Monitoring *Central Air Quality Laboratory *Calibration Laboratory
The work of the Modelling and Expertise Pool department is focused upon: the development of [[Air pollution dispersion modeling|air pollution dispersion models]]; the application of such models in the preparation of expert reports and opinions; forecasts of air quality control; the processing of operating information on pollutant concentrations obtained by the Airborne Monitoring section.
The SYMOS97 air pollution dispersion model was developed at the CHMI. It models the dispersion of [[Air pollution dispersion terminology|continuous, neutral or buoyant plumes]] from single or multiple [[Air pollution dispersion terminology|point, area or line sources]]. It can handle complex terrain and it can also be used to simulate the dispersion of [[cooling tower]] plumes.<ref>[http://pandora.meng.auth.gr/mds/strquery.php?wholedb The Model Documententation System (MDS)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071102135620/http://pandora.meng.auth.gr/mds/strquery.php?wholedb |date=2007-11-02 }} of the European Topic Centre on Air and Climate Change (part of the European Environment Agency)</ref>
==See also==
* [[List of atmospheric dispersion models]] * [[Finnish Meteorological Institute|FMI]], the Finnish Meteorological Institute * [[KNMI (institute)|KNMI]], the Royal Dutch Meteorological Institute * [[NILU]], the Norwegian Institute for Air Research * [[Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute]] * [[Royal Meteorological Society]]
==References== <References/>

{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox protected area | name = Deep Creek Lake State Park | iucn_category = III | iucn_ref = <ref name="IUCN1">{{cite web|title=Deep Creek Lake State Park|url=https://www.protectedplanet.net/deep-creek-lake-state-park|website=Protected Planet|publisher=IUCN|accessdate=1 May 2018}}</ref> <!-- images --> | photo = DCL-May2008.jpg | photo_caption = <!-- map --> | map = USA Maryland | map_image = | map_size = 280 | map_caption = Location in Maryland | relief = 1 <!-- location --> | location = [[Garrett County, Maryland|Garrett]], Maryland, United States | nearest_city = | nearest_town = | coordinates = {{coord|39|31|30|N|79|18|18|W|display=inline,title}} | coords_ref = <ref name=gnis/> <!-- stats --> | length = | length_mi = | length_km = | width = | width_mi = | width_km = | area_acre = 1818 | area_ref = <ref name=2013report/> | elevation = {{convert|2461|ft|m|abbr=on}}<ref name=gnis>{{cite gnis|584060|Deep Creek Lake}}</ref> | elevation_avg = | elevation_min = | elevation_max = | dimensions = | designation = <!-- dates & info --> | authorized = | created = | designated = | established = History | named_for = | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | visitation_ref = | governing_body = | administrator = | operator = [[Maryland Department of Natural Resources]] | owner = <!-- website, embedded --> | website = [http://dnr.maryland.gov/publiclands/Pages/western/deepcreek.aspx Deep Creek Lake State Park] | embedded = }}
'''Deep Creek Lake State Park''' is a state-operated, public recreation area surrounding [[Deep Creek Lake]] in [[Garrett County, Maryland]], in the United States. The park features water activities, camping facilities, and recreational trails and is located about {{convert|18|mi}} south of [[Interstate 68]] on [[U.S. Route 219]].<ref name=mdnr/>
==History== Although settlers arrived in the area in the 1700s, it was the massive logging operations of the 20th century that stripped the land of its virgin forest.<ref name=mdnr/> The park's forest of oaks and hickories was regenerated from the original timber stand.<ref name=mdnr/>
The Deep Creek Lake [[reservoir]] was created on a tributary of the [[Youghiogheny River]] with completion of the [[Deep Creek Dam]] by the [[Pennsylvania Electric Company]] in 1925. The state took charge of recreation on the lake in 1980, then purchased the land underlying the lake and buffer zone properties for $17 million in 2000.<ref name=plan/>
In September 2010, the Appalachian Regional Commission $20,000 in funding for a study of potential development at Deep Creek Lake.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cardin, Mikulski Announce Grant for Study of Economic Impact of Deep Creek Lake|url=https://www.cardin.senate.gov/newsroom/press/release/cardin-mikulski-announce-grant-for-study-of-economic-impact-of-deep-creek-lake|publisher=Senator Ben Cardin|accessdate=October 9, 2017|language=en|date=September 21, 2010}}</ref> An official tourism website promoting Deep Creek Lake was launched soon after by the Garrett County Chamber of Commerce.
==Activities and amenities== Lake activities include motor boating, water skiing, swimming, fishing, and canoeing. A campground has 112 campsites, 26 with electricity. Trails are used for hiking and mountain biking.<ref name=mdnr/> The park's {{convert|6000|sqft|adj=on}} Discovery Center offers exhibits on local plants and wildlife, including the [[American black bears]] occasionally seen in the campground, the lake and its watershed, conservation issues, and local coal and logging activities in addition to the daily educational programs about nature and the environment presented by naturalists, rangers, and volunteers.<ref name=discovery/>
===Johnny's Bait House=== Johnny's Bait House was a business and facility that operated on the shore of Deep Creek Lake from 1955 to 2003.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mountaindiscoveries.com/stories/pdf/fw2003/lakereflections.pdf|title=Lake Reflections|last=|first=|date=2003|publisher=Mountain Discoveries Magazine|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2003-01-23/features/0301230400_1_marple-bait-house-bait-shop|title=Gone Fishin'|newspaper=tribunedigital-baltimoresun|access-date=October 18, 2016}}</ref> It was owned and operated by Johnny Marple and his wife Elaine. Johnny promoted and supported the fishing industry at Deep Creek Lake. In the early years, Johnny's was open year-round, supporting all fishing, including [[ice fishing]], but eventually started closing during the winter months. Johnny's provided the Deep Creek Lake Fishing Report to the Maryland Department of Natural Resources and many publications such as ''The Washington Post'',<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/sports/1993/06/27/the-creek-runs-deep-in-western-maryland/bf5ebad8-0d33-4142-96c0-d65b2c320b42/|title=THE CREEK RUNS DEEP IN WESTERN MARYLAND|last=Phillips|first=Angus|date=June 27, 1993|newspaper=The Washington Post|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286|access-date=October 18, 2016}}</ref> Baltimore Sun, [[Field and Stream Magazine]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0YHCfcqpHawC&lpg=PA64&dq=johnny's%20bait%20house%20deep%20creek%20lake%20about&pg=PA64#v=onepage&q=johnny's%20bait%20house%20deep%20creek%20lake%20about&f=false|title=Field & Stream|date=January 1, 1981|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=EXjB35Lp2_cC&lpg=PA66&dq=johnny's%20bait%20house%20deep%20creek%20lake%20about&pg=PA66#v=onepage&q=johnny's%20bait%20house%20deep%20creek%20lake%20about&f=false|title=Field & Stream|date=January 1, 1997|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=-7sVsG7u91QC&lpg=PA71&dq=johnny's%20bait%20house%20deep%20creek%20lake%20about&pg=PA71#v=onepage&q=johnny's%20bait%20house%20deep%20creek%20lake%20about&f=false|title=Field & Stream|date=October 18, 2016|language=en}}</ref> and Star Democrat.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/93406743/|title=The Star-Democrat from Easton, Maryland · Page 22|website=Newspapers.com|access-date=October 19, 2016}}</ref>
Johnnys partnered with the Garrett County Promotion Council and founded the Garrett County Fishing Contest,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/27775198/|title=The Evening Standard from Uniontown, Pennsylvania · Page 3|website=Newspapers.com|access-date=October 19, 2016}}</ref> a weekly event that continues to this day. The establishment also managed the official Deep Creek Lake Fishing records through 2003. During that time, multiple Maryland state freshwater fishing record catches were registered.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldwideawake.com/JOHNNYS/records.html|title=Maryland and Garrett County Fishing Records - Johnny's Bait House|website=www.worldwideawake.com|access-date=October 18, 2016}}</ref> Johnny assisted the State of Maryland Department of Natural Resources in the monitoring of fish population and the registration of fish tagged for population studies. Many of the collection of mounted fish from that time period are still on display in the Discovery Center of the Deep Creek Lake State Park.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.discoverycenterdcl.com/|title=Deep Creek Lake Discovery Center - Home|website=www.discoverycenterdcl.com|access-date=October 18, 2016}}</ref> The former location of Johnny's is currently occupied by Bill's Outdoor Center.
==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= <ref name=2013report>{{cite web|url=http://dnr.maryland.gov/land/stewardship/pdfs/currentacreagereport.pdf |title=FY2015 DNR Owned Lands Acreage Report |publisher=Maryland DNR |date=August 18, 2015 |accessdate=May 31, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151018234718/http://www.dnr.maryland.gov/land/stewardship/pdfs/CurrentAcreageReport.pdf |archivedate=October 18, 2015 |df= }}</ref>

[[File:Schwimmschnee.jpg|thumb|"Sugar snow" as a layer in a snowpack]] [[File:LightLTSEM.jpg|thumb|Depth hoar crystals, imaged with light and with scanning electron microscopy]] '''Depth hoar''' (also called '''sugar snow''') are large [[crystal]]s occurring at the base of a [[snow]]pack that form when uprising water [[vapor]] [[Deposition (phase transition)|deposits]] or desublimates onto existing snow crystals. Depth hoar crystals are large, sparkly grains with [[facet]]s that can be cup-shaped and that are up to 10 mm in diameter. Depth hoar crystals bond poorly to each other, increasing the risk for [[avalanches]].
The formation of depth hoar in [[Arctic]] or [[Antarctic]] [[firn]] can cause isotopic changes in the accumulating ice. This can influence analysis of ice cores in scientific research.
== External links ==
* [https://avalanche.org/avalanche-encyclopedia/depth-hoar/ The Avalanche Encyclopedia], extensive summary with animation of formation process
[[Category:Snow]] {{meteorology-stub}}

{{Infobox islands | name = Desventuradas Islands | native_name = Islas Desventuradas | sobriquet = | image_name = Desventuradas islands (Chile).jpg | image_size = 250px | image_caption = Map of Desventuradas Islands, also known as ''San Félix'' Islands | image_alt = Map of Desventuradas Islands, also known as ''San Félix'' Islands | map = Pacific Ocean | location = | coordinates = | archipelago = Desventuradas | waterbody = [[Pacific Ocean]] | total_islands = 4 | major_islands = San Ambrosio, San Félix, Gonzalez and Roca Catedral | area_km2 = 5.36 | area_footnotes = (together) | rank = | length_km = | length_footnotes = | width_km = | width_footnotes = | coastline_km = | coastline_footnotes = | elevation_m = 479 | elevation_footnotes =  max. | highest_mount = | Country_heading = | country = {{Flag|Chile}} | country_admin_divisions_title = [[Regions of Chile|Region]] | country_admin_divisions = {{flag|Valparaíso}} | country_admin_divisions_title_1 = [[Provinces of Chile|Province]] | country_admin_divisions_1 = [[Valparaíso Province]] | country_admin_divisions_title_2 = [[Communes of Chile|Commune]] | country_admin_divisions_2 = [[Juan Fernández Islands|Juan Fernández]] | country_capital = | country_largest_city = | country_largest_city_population = | country_leader_title = | country_leader_name = | country_1 = | country_1_admin_divisions_title = | country_1_admin_divisions = | country_1_admin_divisions_title_1 = | country_1_admin_divisions_1 = | country_1_admin_divisions_title_2 = | country_1_admin_divisions_2 = | country_1_capital_city = | country_1_largest_city = | country_1_largest_city_population = | country_1_leader_title = | country_1_leader_name = | demonym = | population = 11 | population_as_of = | density_km2 = | density_footnotes = | ethnic_groups = | website = | additional_info = [[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency|NGA]] UFI=
-900077 "San Ambrosio"
-883263 "Gonzáles"
-900282 "San Félix" }} [[File:Thamnoseris-a.jpg|thumb|View of the vegetation on San Ambrosio Island]] The '''Desventuradas Islands''' ({{lang-es|Islas Desventuradas}},[http://palaeoworks.anu.edu.au/pubs/Andersonetal02.pdf An Archaeological Exploration of Robinson Crusoe Island] {{IPA-es|ˈizlaz ðezβentuˈɾaðas|IPA}}, "Unfortunate Islands" or ''Islas de los Desventurados'', "Islands of the Unfortunate Ones"[http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/C11441335 ADM - Records of the Admiralty, Naval Forces, Royal Marines, Coastguard, and related bodies; ''Pacific Ocean: South America, W Coast: Chile: Islas de los Desventurados and Islas Juan Fernandez;'']) is a group of four small [[island]]s located {{convert|850|km|mi}} off the coast of [[Chile]], northwest of [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]] in the [[Pacific Ocean]].{{WWF ecoregion|id=nt0403|name=San Félix-San Ambrosio Islands temperate forests}} They are considered part of [[Insular Chile]]. Because of their isolation and difficulty of access, there are no human settlements on these islands, but a detachment of the [[Chilean Navy]] is stationed on ''Isla San Félix,'' which also hosts the {{convert|2000|m|ft|adj=on}} [[Isla San Felix Airport]] (ICAO code for the airfield: SCFX). ==History== The islands were first sighted by [[Juan Fernández (explorer)|Juan Fernández]] on 6 November 1574 while voyaging from [[Callao]] to [[Valparaíso]], and perhaps earlier by [[Ferdinand Magellan]] in 1520. [[Pedro Sarmiento de Gamboa]] wrote in 1579 that "they are now called after St. Felix and St. Ambor (i.e. [[Nabor and Felix|Felix and Nabor]])". However, the name of the [[martyr]] Ambor (Nabor) became confused with that of the more famous bishop [[Saint Ambrose]] (San Ambrosio).B. Glanvill Corney, "The Isles of [[Isla San Félix|San Felix]] and San Nabor," ''The [[Geographical]] Journal'', Vol. 56, No. 3 (September 1920), pp. 196–200Brand, Donald D. ''The Pacific Basin: A History of its Geographical Explorations'' The American Geographical Society, New York, 1967, p.127. It is, probably, one of these islands that Captain John Davis struck one night in 1686. He was able to continue his voyage but erroneously reported the position of the incident.{{cite book|author=Jacques Julien Houtou de Labillardière|title=Relation du voyage à la recherche de La Pérouse ... 1791, 1792, et pendant la Ière et la 2de année de la République françoise. 2 tom. [and] Atlas|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-icAAAAAQAAJ|year=1800}} San Felix played a part in the [[Falklands War]]. In May 1982, the Chilean government allowed RAF [[Hawker Siddeley Nimrod|Nimrod MR2s]] to fly maritime reconnaissance sorties from the island, gathering information on the movements of the Argentine Navy.{{cite web|url=http://www.spyflight.co.uk/chile.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120430000000/http://www.spyflight.co.uk/chile.htm |archivedate=2012-04-30 |df= }}{{cite news|last1=Alexander|first1=Harriet|title='Without Chile's help, we would have lost the Falklands'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/southamerica/falklandislands/10947350/Without-Chiles-help-we-would-have-lost-the-Falklands.html|accessdate=8 July 2014|work=The Telegraph|date=7 July 2014}} ==Ecology== The [[vegetation]] of the larger islands is a miniature mosaic of [[matorral]], barren rock, various size trees, and shrubs mixed with ferns and perennial herbs. ''[[Thamnoseris lacerata]]'' is an endemic shrub species. There are no permanent sources of fresh water on any of the islands. Vertebrates inhabiting both of the largest islands are limited to birds. Ten [[species]] of [[marine bird]]s and one land bird species, some of them endangered, make their nests on or visit the islands. ==List of islands and location== The Desventuradas Islands, from east to west: {| class="wikitable" |-style="background: #CCC;" ! align ="left"|Island/Rock || align="right"| Area
(km²)|| Peak

{{short description|A series of scientific cruises and shore-based investigations into the biology of whales in the Southern Ocean}} [[File:StateLibQld 1 149327 Discovery (ship).jpg|thumb|400px|The former Antarctic exploration ship [[RRS Discovery|RSS ''Discovery'']] was employed for the Discovery Investigations cruises between 1923 and 1931.]]The '''Discovery Investigations''' were a series of scientific cruises and shore-based investigations into the biology of whales in the [[Southern Ocean]]. They were funded by the [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Colonial Office]] and organised by the [[Discovery Committee]] in London, which was formed in 1918. They were intended to provide the scientific background to stock management of the commercial Antarctic whale fishery. The work of the Investigations contributed hugely to our knowledge of the whales, the krill they fed on, and the oceanography of their habitat, while charting the local topography, including [[Atherton Peak]]. The investigations continued until 1951, with the final report being published in 1980. ==Laboratory == Shore-based work on [[South Georgia Island|South Georgia]] took place in the marine laboratory, [[Discovery House]], built in 1925 at [[King Edward Point]] and occupied until 1931. The scientists lived and worked in the building, travelling half a mile or so across [[King Edward Cove]] to the whaling station at [[Grytviken]] to work on whales as they were brought ashore by commercial whaling ships. ==Ships == Vessels used were: *[[RRS Discovery|RRS ''Discovery'']] from 1924 to 1931 *[[RRS William Scoresby|RRS ''William Scoresby'']] from 1927 to 1945 or later{{cite book |title=Exploring Polar Frontiers: A Historical Encyclopedia, Volume 1 |last=Mills |first=William James |publisher=ABC-CLIO |year=2003 |isbn=1576074226 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PYdBH4dOOM4C |accessdate=2012-08-17}} *[[RRS Discovery II|RRS ''Discovery II'']] from 1929 to 1951 ==Reports == Results of the investigations were printed in the Discovery Reports. This was a series of many small reports, published in 38 volumes by the [[Cambridge University Press]], and latterly the [[Institute of Oceanographic Sciences]]. Many were printed as individual reports rather than in large volumes. ===List of the Discovery Reports=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Volume Pages/Plates/Charts ! Title ! Author ! Published |- ! colspan="4" align="left" | === Volume I === |- | | List of Personnel | | |- | pp. 1–140

Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom, Plymouth | March 1980 |- |} == Books == The Discovery Investigations are described in the following books, all of which were out of print in 2008: * ''Great Waters'' by Sir [[Alister Hardy]] - Collins, 1967 * ''South Latitude'' by F D Ommanney - Longmans, 1938 * ''Discovery II In The Antarctic'' by John Coleman-Cooke - Odhams, 1963 * ''A Camera in Antarctica'' by Alfred Saunders - Winchester Publications, London, 1950 ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/bibliography/6168 Scanned copies] of many of the reports are available at the [[Biodiversity Heritage Library]]. [[Category:History of South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands]] [[Category:History of Earth science]] [[Category:Biological oceanography]] [[Category:Antarctic expeditions]]
